Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

Scientists studying transcription in yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) created an experimental strain that produced a modified <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></math> polymerase containing a single amino acid substitution. The scientists determined the maximum elongation rate during transcription with and without the modified <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></math> polymerase enzyme (Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>).

The compound amanitin, which is commonly found in toxic mushrooms, is a specific <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></math> polymerase inhibitor. Amanitin binds to the <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></math> polymerase active site and inhibits transcription. In a second experiment, the scientists treated the wild-type and experimental strains of S. cerevisiae with a <math alttext="40 micrograms per milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>40</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>μg</mtext><mtext></mtext><mtext></mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></math> solution of amanitin and recorded the maximum elongation rate of the <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></math> (Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 standard errors of the mean" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext></mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></math>.

Explain the role of <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></math> polymerase during transcription.

frqParts.text: (a) Describe the three structural components of an <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></math> nucleotide monomer. Explain the role of <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></math> polymerase during transcription.
(b) Identify the dependent variable in the experiments. Identify a control group missing from the second experiment. Justify the need for this control group in the second experiment.

(c) Describe the effect of amanitin on the maximum elongation rate for the wild-type and modified <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></math> polymerases. Determine the ratio of the average maximum elongation rate for the modified <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></math> polymerase compared to the wild strain <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> polymerase in Figure 1.

(d) State the null hypothesis for the experiment in Figure 1. Provide reasoning to justify the claim that the change in the amino acid sequence in the modified <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></math> polymerase affected the shape of the active site on the enzyme.
